title: Thursday, 6th September 2018
bodyHTML:
11:08 am
BE11:08am

Hello.

Blank canvas good morning everyone
Soundbuy Morning
Manxish Morning each
Pizza Hey !
Excel Developer Hello, WPP down 4.73% !
BE11:09am

I'm an anonymous insider that is part of the resistance inside the Financial Times.

BE11:10am

Not really, of course! I just sit here and type until they let me go home each evening. Where do we start today?

11:10 am
BE11:11am

(@Excel: where do you get your prices, dude? It's off 0.1%.)

Stateless Morning all
Excel Developer oh investing.com has a bug
nichoman the new pricing service from zerohedge.com
BE11:11am

Dan's already nicked the picture I intended to use to open the session.

Soundbuy Confused with Weir? That's off 6% ish.........
Stateless And as much as I don't like Trump. This resistance fellow reflects the worst parts of the anti-Trump movement. imo
nichoman adds a bit of drama to markets when they're too quiet for punters' liking
BE11:12am

11:12 am
BE11:12am

Yeah .... that's ..... something.

Stateless Seems like that has Sirius potential
BE11:13am

It's from Sirius's presentation explaining why they need up to $600m for a wider hole in the ground.

BE11:13am

https://siriusmine...te-september-2018/

Soundbuy So Sirius looks to be more of a ....... sausage than a pie
GBKrona Hola!
11:13 am
BE11:14am

Dan talks us through the detail here: https://ftalphavil...t-Sirius-Minerals/

hedgehog go ahead ?
BE11:14am

On the financing front, chief executive Chris Fraser also dangled a possibility of an unnamed white night, which may be enough to keep bulletin board interest in the stock alive, even though it would dilute the value of Sirius equity. He said on the call with analysts “we'll be looking to strategic partners” and mentioned the possibility of “bringing in a partner with a bigger balance sheet that Sirius minerals”.

So the company now has a “chicken and egg” problem as one analyst put it. It must secure senior bank finance, conditional on a final capital raise of equity or some form of subordinated debt, and then finish it all up with a UK government guarantee against perhaps $1.5bn of lending.

BE11:15am

Yeah ....... a strategic partner's not really good news tho, assuming they'd take equity rather than .... uh, nothing.

11:15 am
BE11:15am

What we have here is a soft warning for shareholders to expect dilution pre the Q1 2019 funding deadline.

Patience Sirius - dog or star? Can't be both :-(
BE11:16am

Against that you have a bunch of updates on offtake agreements .....

Stateless @Patience - it might be both " The Dog Star, Sirius, in the constellation Canis Major "
BE11:17am

... where Sirius continues to arbitrage its ability to pre-sell to some rather unfamiliar names in the Far East against the potential of securing UK government support.

11:17 am
BE11:18am

Let me grab Liberum's latest rejig of figures.

BE11:18am

While we don't have a clear view at this stage as to the valuation impact resulting from how the incremental c.$500m of capex will be financed, we are confident the project economics (70% EBITDA margin and peak EBITDA c.$2bn at spot) are compelling enough to deliver the financing, particularly with a further 3mtpa of binding offtake. That the shares trade at a 60-70% discount to our NPV range should also provide support.

BE11:18am

However, in line with our conservative pricing and cost profile, we now run a base case scenario that
involves a further $400m of equity being raised, via either a strategic, equity or convertible at 30p.
This reduces our diluted NPV/share to 84p (from 108p) and our target price to 50p (from 60p).

Excel Developer #Trump: POTUS is a man-baby, just as parents keep pills out of reach, Trump's staff have to whisk dangerous executive orders of his desk.
11:18 am
BE11:19am

Liberum also notes the slightly slower ramp-up, with 20mtpa reached in 2029 instead of 2027 .....

Patience @Stateless - exactly.
BE11:19am

... and here comes the valuation chart on the cash call, whatever form it takes.

BE11:20am

11:21 am
BE11:21am

They're buyers, needless to say.

BE11:23am

And house broker -- along with JPM Caz and WH Ireland, just in case you were wondering what the roster looks like if you want to split actual capital-raising requirements with bulletin board nuttery.

undefined
11:23 am
BE11:24am

Weir mentioned earlier.

Weir Group PLC (WEIR:LSE): Last: 1,677, down 109 (-6.10%), High: 1,699, Low: 1,640, Volume: 1.24m
BE11:24am

Problem is Permian.

11:24 am
BE11:24am

And a slowdown in original equipment orders

BE11:26am

This is an unscheduled update ahead of an investor roadshow where awkward questions might've been asked, so Weir's pre-empting of that is something to applaud.

BE11:27am

Gist here is that over the past two weeks, Weir's the aftermarket business had begun to see signs of
pricing pressure and a big softening in demand for original equipment

11:27 am
BE11:27am

As well as some order book delivery deferrals

BE11:28am

Whether two weeks of trading is overly significant is the unknown here.

BE11:28am

Here's UBS.

11:28 am
BE11:28am

Current consensus expects a 20% y/y increase (UBSe 15% y/y) in 2H18 Oil & Gas revenues, implying a 13% sequential increase 2H on 1H. In a scenario where Weir's Oil & Gas revenues hold flat in the 2H, this implies a 7% cut to Oil & Gas revenues (2% to Group revenues). Given the considerable amount of operating leverage in the business, we estimate a 15% impact to Oil & Gas EBITA, bringing the margin to ~14%, compared to current consensus of 15.8% (UBSe 15.3%). This would result in a 5% cut to Group EBITA and a 6% cut to Group EPS.

BE11:29am

Note also Slumberger and Halliburton both warning in recent days of US shale-related bottlenecks

Patience Testing....
BE11:30am

The issue remains how long this softness continues (we continue to believe that this is a temporary issue, although it is still painful and won't be resolved overnight).

11:30 am
BE11:30am

That's Jefferies.

undefined
Excel Developer Is Centrica up 5%?
BE11:30am

I see I've bored the ROTR into silence.

Excel Developer https://www.standard.co.uk/business/centrica-shares-leap-amid-relief-over-may-s-energy-price-cap-move-a3929206.html
Pharma @BE - "bored" I see what you did there...
11:31 am
BE11:31am

Turning to Centrica, SVT price cap innit.

Centrica PLC (CNA:LSE): Last: 150.80, up 7.4 (+5.16%), High: 151.45, Low: 147.50, Volume: 15.42m
BE11:32am

The standard variable tariff is capped at £1,136 a year, which is more or less where consensus was.

11:32 am
BE11:33am

Though from here it gets complicated.

GBKrona DId I understand the price cap correcly, that it is an absolute limit??THerefore I can buy a big castle and heat it up to the brim, and still only pay the 1,1,36???How absurd.
Flaneur Morning all, I wonder if the good burghers of FTAV could assist me with something?
BE11:34am

The positive from Ofgem is clarity. Centrica's already said that level of cap is manageable.

BE11:34am

As per Jefferies:

11:34 am
BE11:34am

Following its recent tariff increase, Centrica is expected to charge £1,205/year for SVT direct debit customers from October. Ofgem's proposed cap level of £1,136 implies a £70 reduction on Centrica's SVT with the price cap (or £210m for 3m SVT customers). We see this as encouraging given the level of the cap is ahead of our own and consensus expectations, and is well within the £100/year impact that management recently communicated to us as being manageable for its 12p DPS guidance. In our view, this should help to alleviate the two year overhang on the stock.

Lemmy GBKrona: alas, otherwise I'd advise readers to open an aluminium smelting plants in their shed. It's the cap for a typical home
BE11:35am

And as per Citi.

Pharma Price cap = slightly lower prices for people who never look at their bills, and slightly higher prices for those who do.Deckchairs, meet government.
BE11:35am

On first sight, the direct debt price cap of £1,136 is broadly in-line with consensus of £1,130 and marginally ahead of our forecast. The standard credit cap of £1,219 is £83 ahead of the direct debit cap, more than our assumed £50. In our view, we believe the price cap proposal today should appease politically also.
As we highlighted in Diamond in the rough, the price cap (assuming no major changes from the proposals today) should provide a good degree of earnings visibility for the retail companies including Centrica and SSE. Furthermore, we believe this, together with the higher commodity prices, should help to underpin the 12p DPS at Centrica. We reiterate our Buy rating for Centrica (PT of 160p) and rate SSE as Neutral.

GBKrona @lemmy - or outgrowers for certain Canadian agricultural companies growing weedy stuff?
11:36 am
BE11:36am

And as per RBC.

BE11:36am

Overall we continue to see retail markets in the UK as challenging with high levels of political focus, regulatory scrutiny and intense competition from smaller
suppliers. However, this morning’s news acts as a line in the sand, starts to give clarity on future margins and has removed some of the downside risk to market
expectations.

lastman standing good morning
lastman standing back again after the summer VOD took a beating
Soundbuy Dechra Pharma still being hammered
BE11:37am

Macquarie, however, has gone for the trouble of actually reading the Ofgem doc.

Excel Developer @Bryce: The Evening Standard's business pages now have a salmon pink hue! #Cultural appropriation
11:37 am
BE11:37am

And is less enthused.

Lemmy GBKrona: such a cold climate to grow that in, no?
BE11:38am

[W]hen looking at the comparisons between our method and reported method, we see a higher wholesale cost allowance, versus ours, and a lower allowed margin+headroom, albeit allowed profit looks higher (£20 versus £15). This provides an allowed EBIT of 2.8% versus our 4.0% estimate (£15 EBIT + £30 headroom = £45). A fall of c.1% in margin in SVT would decrease EBIT by c.£30m, or 0.5p/share EPS for Centrica and 1.5p/share for SSE.

GBKrona @Lemmy - but here we will have subsidised heating, so Britain can be a great exporter again.
BE11:39am

Overall margin impact is what matters, says Macquarie.

11:39 am
undefined
BE11:39am

Vodafone? Sure. Vodafone.

Vodafone Group PLC (VOD:LSE): Last: 165.24, up 2.34 (+1.44%), High: 167.22, Low: 163.22, Volume: 27.33m
11:39 am
BE11:40am

Second upgrade in two days.

BE11:40am

Yesterday it was Bernstein saying, "the divi's not covered but if the Liberty deal gets EU approval it might be one day."

BE11:41am

Today it's Citi saying, "the divi's not covered but the credit markets aren't pricing in a cut so why are you, you dolt?"

Pharma @Excel a cynic might say that the whole paper has a pinkish hue with Osborne in charge.
11:41 am
BE11:41am

VOD is not a clean story; a stock that yields c.8.5% seldom fits that profile. But VOD is committed to its dividend and its growth outlook. We believe the dividend may be at risk, but will only be cut if VOD is forced by the market to cut it. Such a scenario could most likely be triggered by the credit markets. Only if bond yields rise to levels that force management to shift priorities and focus on deleveraging would VOD look at cutting its dividend in our view. That is not the case at this point. The equity has de-rated on fear of the dividend being at risk; the credit - which can put it at risk- has not.

BE11:42am

Which ....... yeah. It's not a perfect argument is it?

BE11:42am

Though Citi concedes as much.

Excel Developer Fildeity China Special Sits is so large it's in the FTSE350. Great investment that looked like it was immune to China woes due to fund manager's excellent stock selection. Sadly even FCSS is over 20% off now. Trade/tariff woes probs.
11:42 am
BE11:42am

At least one of the markets is wrong (potentially both). But we see upside risk for VOD shares in the near term unless the credit markets not just deteriorate but do so meaningfully. We believe over time that may well happen but is not a given and is not that likely in the near term. That in isolation may warrant upside.

BE11:43am

Odd that Bernstein's note yesterday -- essentially saying that Vodafone won't be the same company by next spring -- was widely ignored whereas Citi's -- essentially saying that debt prices are likely to be stickier than equity so buy the equity -- has been welcomed.

undefined
11:45 am
BE11:45am

What else we got?

Soundbuy Melrose?
wayneJ What is 'an unnamed white night'? typo?
GBKrona @BE - very bullish upgrade of RB by JP Morgan??
TB Nick Read presenting for the first time as CEO designate at GS Communacopia conference in NY next week
BE11:47am

(@wayneJ: I'll have someone fix that.)

BE11:48am

Melrose H1's fine.

Excel Developer Redrow +3.38%; Bovis Homes +3.67%; Barrat +1.91%
wayneJ Re Weir - it was on a broker list as an acquisition candidate earlier this year; the other industrial on that list was GKN (sorry can't remember which broker) - argument that the business will be easy to split into a couple of parts.
11:48 am
BE11:49am

GKN seems to be okay. Management saying margin can go beyond 10% from
c.7%.

BE11:49am

Which is in line with the pre-acquisition guidance, but generally reassuring in context

BE11:49am

And there are no nasties uncovered yet. Again, reassuring rather than surprising.

wayneJ Re Permian - the issue is that the pipelines out the Permian are full to capacity; so drilled but uncompleted wells going through the roof - but in many ways that is equivalent to a potential 'backlog' of orders for Weir et al when new pipelines start H2 next yr
11:50 am
BE11:50am

Here's JPM Caz.

wayneJ The other point is that some rig capacity (or people) is being diverted to other shale areas in the interim.
BE11:51am

Melrose’s Interims and initial strategy update for GKN ticks all the boxes:
1) Group trading is in line, the H1 run-rate is ahead of our forecasts and
2018 management’s expectations are unchanged, 2) early progress at GKN
has been significant and no black holes have been found, and, 3)
management has reconfirmed all acquisition commitments and targets. Our forecasts increase for all years and our view on the stock is unchanged; we continue to see significant upside to earnings and for shareholders as management executes its ‘Buy, Improve, Sell’ model at GKN. We do not see the upside captured in the current share price which, after a period where top-down news flow has weighed on the stock, we now expect it to outperform. We reiterate our Overweight rating with a new December 2019 price target of 285p.

BE11:51am

Key points. 1) Management expectations are unchanged for 2018 and
the H1’18 run-rate is ahead of our model. 2) Management has not found
any black holes at GKN and early progress has been significant both in
terms of improvement initiatives and investment. 3) Management’s
expectations remain that GKN offers an outstanding opportunity to
create shareholder value and pre-acquisition commitments are
reconfirmed including to exceed the 10% margin target. 4) Management
is exploring strategic options for Powder Metallurgy. 5) Nortek
continues to trade in line with our expectations.

Excel Developer I suppose Budget speculation can drive some stocks in the weeks leading up to Budget.
11:51 am
undefined
BE11:52am

Speaking of industrials .............

BE11:52am

...................... interesting thing from Liberum out this morning.

11:52 am
BE11:52am

Their cap goods indicator's flashing red and they're saying sell nearly everything.

lastman standing thank you BE, i'm in VOD lots, and needed a little reassurance
Bodycote PLC (BOY:LSE): Last: 898.65, down 42.85 (-4.55%), High: 931.00, Low: 896.00, Volume: 235.56k
IMI PLC (IMI:LSE): Last: 1,153, down 51 (-4.24%), High: 1,190, Low: 1,153, Volume: 391.64k
Soundbuy Weir could do with Melrosing..........
11:54 am
Smiths Group PLC (SMIN:LSE): Last: 1,597, no change, High: 1,605, Low: 1,585, Volume: 146.15k
wayneJ @Soundbuy - I suspect you are not the only one who has made that observation.
BE11:55am

Along with Sandvik, SKF and Schneider in Europe. The note's taking forever to open

BE11:56am

Our Early Cycle Indicator (ECI) has fallen from a peak above 1.20 to
below 1.10, a key sector sell signal. The sector has sold off on six of the
seven previous occasions this has happened in the last 20 years, with an
average decline of 33% in eight months. In prior periods with flat yield
curves the sell-off was greater, while high inventories and extended
delivery times may also cause further pressure.

11:56 am
BE11:56am

The what now? You have to turn to page 52 to find out.

BE11:57am

Our proprietary Early Cycle Indicator (ECI) is used to forecast the organic
sales growth of early-cycle businesses, such as Bodycote’s Automotive
& General Industrial division (AGI). [It] forecasts organic sales growth for early-cycle businesses whose revenues are driven by industrial production (rather than capex). Back-tested over 20 years, the ECI has an 80% correlation with organic growth and leads by 6-9 months.

Soundbuy Aye..........
wayneJ I would humbly suggest that there are two charts Weir investors ought to familiarise themselves with - 'drilled and completed' and 'drilled and uncompleted' wells in the US - and if you want more detail it is possible to go down to the Permian basin alone for both those. One chart gives you in essence current activity and the other gives you a virtual orderbook. I am happy to provide both charts to Weir management on a regular basis for a fee......(you know using Google is a value add service...:-) )
BE11:57am

And it looks like this:

11:57 am
BE11:57am

BE11:58am

Oops, sorry, wrong chart.

wayneJ Drilled uncompleted is exploding. (Not sure if Bryce can find the charts on his terminal?)
BE11:58am

I meant this one, with the red dots of doom.

11:58 am
BE11:58am

BE11:59am

11:59 am
BE12:00pm

I know we started late but we're also finishing on time.

BE12:00pm

Go here if you want more: https://www.ft.com...-8d14-6f049d06439c

Excel Developer Cheers Bryce. Final remark today, congratulations to India for stepping out of the dark ages re #LGBT. If you value human rights then investing in EM typically involves holding your nose or looking the other way. Less so today.
wayneJ Thanks for trying, BE. Another interesting chart is wage inflation in the Permian
BE12:00pm

From that I'd highlight a very interesting Redburn sell note on HSBC.

12:00 pm
HSBC Holdings PLC (HSBA:LSE): Last: 664.70, down 5.4 (-0.81%), High: 669.10, Low: 664.20, Volume: 6.74m
BE12:01pm

Which they'll probably shout at me for reporting, but never mind. It's all worth it for you, dear reader.

BE12:03pm

Also, if you haven't, take a moment to read the letter from Videndi moaning about Elliott's stewardship of Telecom Italia.

12:02 pm
BE12:03pm

http://www.vivendi...talia-and-vivendi/

BE12:03pm

"disastrous"

BE12:04pm

The new governance team is failing: the spreading of rumors (including the departure of the CEO) is causing dysfunction that is harmful to the smooth operation and results of TIM.

Soundbuy Cheers all...........must dash
12:04 pm
BE12:04pm

I should also note that TI's Fulvio Conti calls these “absurd and unfounded accusations"

BE12:05pm

And it all gets a bit 1494 from there. Lots of "how dare you yomp across the Alps and tell us what do do".

BE12:06pm

(1494 was Charles VIII, wasn't it? History lessons were a very long time ago.)

Pharma @BE isn't that 218 BC?
12:06 pm
BE12:06pm

Anyway.

BE12:07pm

Ta for joining. Ta for the comments.

GBKrona thanks @BE / ROTR
BE12:07pm

Back tomorrow. Afternoon all.

Pharma Hannibal 'n' all
